column3: Ah, cried Valentine suddenly, "I understand.

column2: It is my marriage you mean, is it not, dear grandpapa?"
column3: It is my marriage you mean, is it not, dear grandpapa?"

column2: Yes, yes, yes, signed the paralytic, casting on Valentine a look of joyful gratitude for having guessed his meaning.
column3: Yes, yes, yes, signed the paralytic, casting on Valentine a look of joyful gratitude for having guessed his meaning.

column2: You are angry with us all on account of this marriage, are you not?
column3: You are angry with us all on account of this marriage, are you not?

column2: Yes?
column3: Yes?

column2: Really, this is too absurd, said Villefort.
column3: Really, this is too absurd, said Villefort.

column2: Excuse me, sir, replied the notary; "on the contrary, the meaning of M. Noirtier is quite evident to me, and I can quite easily connect the train of ideas passing in his mind."
column3: Excuse me, sir, replied the notary; "on the contrary, the meaning of m Noirtier is quite evident to me, and I can quite easily connect the train of ideas passing in his mind."

column2: You do not wish me to marry M. Franz d'Epinay? observed Valentine.
column3: You do not wish me to marry m Franz d'Epinay? observed Valentine.

column2: I do not wish it, said the eye of her grandfather.
column3: I do not wish it, said the eye of her grandfather.

column2: And you disinherit your granddaughter, continued the notary, "because she has contracted an engagement contrary to your wishes?"
column3: And you disinherit your granddaughter, continued the notary, "because she has contracted an engagement contrary to your wishes?"

column2: Yes.
column3: Yes.

column2: So that, but for this marriage, she would have been your heir?
column3: So that, but for this marriage, she would have been your heir?

column2: Yes. There was a profound silence.
column3: Yes. There was a profound silence.

column2: The two notaries were holding a consultation as to the best means of proceeding with the affair. Valentine was looking at her grandfather with a smile of intense gratitude, and Villefort was biting his lips with vexation, while Madame de Villefort could not succeed in repressing an inward feeling of joy, which, in spite of herself, appeared in her whole countenance.
column3: The two notaries were holding a consultation as to the best means of proceeding with the affair. Valentine was looking at her grandfather with a smile of intense gratitude, and Villefort was biting his lips with vexation, while Madame de Villefort could not succeed in repressing an inward feeling of joy, which, in spite of herself, appeared in her whole countenance.

column2: But, said Villefort, who was the first to break the silence, "I consider that I am the best judge of the propriety of the marriage in question.
column3: But, said Villefort, who was the first to break the silence, "I consider that I am the best judge of the propriety of the marriage in question.

column2: I am the only person possessing the right to dispose of my daughter's hand. It is my wish that she should marry M. Franz d'Epinay--and she shall marry him." Valentine sank weeping into a chair.
column3: I am the only person possessing the right to dispose of my daughter's hand. It is my wish that she should marry m Franz d'Epinay-and she shall marry him." Valentine sank weeping into a chair.

column2: Sir, said the notary, "how do you intend disposing of your fortune in case Mademoiselle de Villefort still determines on marrying M. Franz?" The old man gave no answer.
column3: Sir, said the notary, "how do you intend disposing of your fortune in case Mademoiselle de Villefort still determines on marrying m Franz?" The old man gave no answer.

column2: You will, of course, dispose of it in some way or other?
column3: You will, of course, dispose of it in some way or other?

column2: Yes.
column3: Yes.

column2: In favor of some member of your family?
column3: In favor of some member of your family?

column2: No.
column3: no

column2: Do you intend devoting it to charitable purposes, then? pursued the notary.
column3: Do you intend devoting it to charitable purposes, then? pursued the notary.

column2: Yes.
column3: Yes.

column2: But, said the notary, "you are aware that the law does not allow a son to be entirely deprived of his patrimony?"
column3: But, said the notary, "you are aware that the law does not allow a son to be entirely deprived of his patrimony?"

column2: Yes.
column3: Yes.

column2: You only intend, then, to dispose of that part of your fortune which the law allows you to subtract from the inheritance of your son? Noirtier made no answer.
column3: You only intend, then, to dispose of that part of your fortune which the law allows you to subtract from the inheritance of your son? Noirtier made no answer.

column2: Do you still wish to dispose of all?
column3: Do you still wish to dispose of all?

column2: Yes.
column3: Yes.

column2: But they will contest the will after your death?
column3: But they will contest the will after your death?

column2: No.
column3: no

column2: My father knows me, replied Villefort; "he is quite sure that his wishes will be held sacred by me; besides, he understands that in my position I cannot plead against the poor." The eye of Noirtier beamed with triumph.
column3: My father knows me, replied Villefort; "he is quite sure that his wishes will be held sacred by me; besides, he understands that in my position I cannot plead against the poor." The eye of Noirtier beamed with triumph.

column2: What do you decide on, sir? asked the notary of Villefort.
column3: What do you decide on, sir? asked the notary of Villefort.

column2: Nothing, sir; it is a resolution which my father has taken and I know he never alters his mind.	Nothing, sir; it is a resolution which my father has taken and I know he never alters his mind.
column3: true

column2: I am quite resigned.
column3: I am quite resigned.

column2: These 900,000 francs will go out of the family in order to enrich some hospital; but it is ridiculous thus to yield to the caprices of an old man, and I shall, therefore, act according to my conscience." Having said this, Villefort quitted the room with his wife, leaving his father at liberty to do as he pleased.
column3: These nine hundred thousand francs will go out of the family in order to enrich some hospital; but it is ridiculous thus to yield to the caprices of an old man, and I shall, therefore, act according to my conscience." Having said this, Villefort quitted the room with his wife, leaving his father at liberty to do as he pleased.

column2: The same day the will was made, the witnesses were brought, it was approved by the old man, sealed in the presence of all and given in charge to M. Deschamps, the family notary.
column3: The same day the will was made, the witnesses were brought, it was approved by the old man, sealed in the presence of all and given in charge to m Deschamps, the family notary.
